text: Our town is part of the US Eastern deciduous forest region. What evidence of that can we observe outside?

Activity: Work with your group and use a text box to make a list in your 'My Work: Reference' space of what you expect to find when you go look around your environment. What are your references? (view out the window, classroom/home/ library books, Ranger Rick magazines?) You can drag images on your computer onto your Reference space too.
Make a new text box by clicking the 'A' tool. You can drag text blocks and images from the lesson into your page too.
Let’s go outside! Bring your science notebook to make notes and drawings of what you find. When you come back inside, add your top three observations to your Practice space on My Work.
You can make drawings of what you find by choosing the pencil tool in the Workspace. Try making a table of data with the number or type of different things you found.

Encourage your students to try making drawings of the leaves and plants they find. See if they can make a table with the kinds of data they take - sizes and types of leaves or trees, counts of different species, etc.

Compare notes with your groupmates!

  • What different types of evidence of Eastern deciduous forest did you observe? What did you expect to see that you did not see?
  • What did you see that you didn't expect (didn’t list in Reference?)

If you use time as a variable that changes, what might you expect to see that would be different in four weeks? Why? How could you test your hypothesis?
Work with your group and use a text box to list your findings and plan an experiment in your CLUE My Work Experiment space. Choose the Share switch to make your ideas show in the group view.
